body: Thought leaders in the insurance industry such as the ABI, PWC, and Hitachi all agree: GDPR is a big shake-up, and will cause significant disruption to how insurers store, manage and process personal data. However, it should also be treated as an opportunity to provide better, more efficient services to customers.
title: What are the impacts of the GDPR for Lloyd's of London?
instruction: Explore the threats and opportunities below:

_items.title: Threats
_items.body:
Significant penalties can be imposed on organisations who breach the GDPR, including fines of up to 20 million euros or 4% of a company’s turnover (whichever is larger) per breach.

The supervisory authority may also issue a corrective order that an organisation must comply with. 

Corrective powers include, amongst other things: issuing warnings; ordering compliance with a individual's requests to exercise their rights; ordering compliance with the GDPR; and, ordering restrictions on data processing activities including the permanent deletion of personal data.

In addition to monetary fines and actions, breaching the GDPR may result in significant reputational damage to the organisation.

_items.title: Opportunities
_items.body:
Understanding what personal data an organisation holds and how it is processed helps reduce risk of such data falling into the wrong hands. 

Additionally such practices can help to:

  • deduplicate data, saving storage space
  • identify linkages between data processing and points of engagement with customers
  • deliver a better set of services

body:
The GDPR makes 'privacy by design' a legal requirement at the start of any project that will be processing personal data in any way. For example when:

  • designing and building new IT systems for storing or accessing personal data
  • using personal data for new purposes
  • onboarding a new supplier
  • developing policies or strategies with privacy implications;
  • embarking on a data sharing initiative

If you are introducing a new process you should contact the Data Protection Office to arrange for a Data Protection Impact Assessment (DPIA) to be completed before any action is taken.
displayTitle: If you are introducing a new process...
title: If you are introducing a new process...

body:
The GDPR is breached if a security incident occurs that affects the confidentiality, integrity or availability of personal data. Personal data breaches include, but are not restricted to the following:

  • Loss, theft, alteration or unauthorised destruction of data or documents containing personal data
  • Loss or theft of equipment or devices on which personal data is stored (e.g. mobile phone, laptop, computer hard drive, USB stick, CD, iPad/tablet device, voice recorder, servers etc.) either owned by Lloyd’s or a personally owned device
  • Unauthorised use of, access to or modification of data or IT systems
  • Incorrect or unauthorised sharing or disclosure of personal data
  • Human error (social media incident, unauthorised access to building & systems etc.)

Importantly, these include breaches that are the result of both accidental and deliberate causes.
title: Recognising a personal data breach?

body:
If no lawful basis exists, or the lawful basis has expired, you may need to dispose of the personal data.

There are a couple of techniques that can be adopted to retain usability of data where no lawful basis for retention of personal exists.
title: Do you need, or are you allowed to keep the personal data?

_items.title: Data Anonymisation
_items.body:
In certain cases, you may need to anonymise data in such a way that the individual is no longer identifiable.

For example, data may be required to be kept for reporting of aggregate statistics, such as engagement figures and event attendance.

The ICO has also produced a code of practice for anonymisation.

_items.title: Data minimisation and deletion
_items.body:
The practice of data minimisation is about limiting the personal data to only that which is relevant and absolutely necessary for carrying out the purpose for which the data is processed.

If there is no longer a lawful basis that justifies the holding of personal data, it should be deleted.

Further details can be found in the master retention schedule or you can contact the DPO for advice.

body:
One of main changes brought in by the GDPR is the addition or enhancement of a number of individual rights. Depending on the lawful basis individuals have the right to:

  • be informed about how personal data about them is being being processed;
  • be given a description of the personal data, the reasons it is being processed, and whether it will be given to any other organisations or people;
  • be given a copy of the information comprising the data; and given details of the source of the data (where this is available).

An individual can also request information about the reasoning behind any automated decisions, such as a computer-generated decision to grant or deny credit.

If you receive a data subject request (including a subject access request) you should immediately contact the Data Protection Office at data.protection@lloyds.com. Failure to do so could result in the request not being responded to within the legal time frame.
title: Respecting the rights of individuals

body:
The data covered by the GDPR is ‘personal data’. This means any information relating to a living person who can be directly or indirectly identified, in particular by reference to an identifier such as an email address or date of birth.

In the case of Lloyd’s, data that would fall into the scope of ‘personal data' includes (but is not limited to):  HR and employee records, supplier lists, member information, market participation information, third party information, complaints information, and, in certain circumstances, policy holder information.

_items.text: The consequences of breaching the GDPR are insignificant

Additionally, GDPR presents opportunities for Lloyd's of London including more effective use of data, and reducing the risk of reputational damage.

body:
The GDPR requires everyone to process personal data lawfully, fairly and in a transparent manner. 

There are six lawful bases outlined in the GDPR. At least one must apply. Without a lawful basis, it is illegal to collect and process personal data.
displayTitle: If you are handling personal data…
title: If you are handling personal data…
instruction: Explore the six lawful basis and how they apply to Lloyd's of London

_items.title: Consent
_items.body: The individual has given clear consent for you to process their personal data for a specific purpose.

_items.title: Contract
_items.body: The processing is necessary for a contract you have with the individual, or because they have asked you to take specific steps before entering into a contract.

_items.title: Legal Obligation
_items.body:
The processing is necessary for you to comply with the law (not including contractual obligations).

Much of the processing of HR records is covered by the lawful basis of legal obligation, for example when Lloyd's of London we are required to disclose employee salary details to HMRC.

_items.title: Vital Interests
_items.body: The processing is necessary to protect someone’s life.

_items.title: Public Task
_items.body: The processing is necessary for you to perform a task in the public interest or for your official functions, and the task or function has a clear basis in law.

_items.title: Legitimate Interests
_items.body:
The processing is necessary for your legitimate interests or the legitimate interests of a third party unless there is a good reason to protect the individual’s personal data which overrides those legitimate interests. 

Some of the processing of HR records is covered by the lawful basis of legitimate interest. For example, in HR Grievance and Discipline Management, data processing is necessary in the legitimate interests of Lloyd's employees (who expect a process whereby grievances can be raised and heard) and Lloyd’s as an employer (who need procedures in place to deal with grievances and disciplinary issues).

body: The three case studies below illustrate different types of breaches, some based on real cases, others fictional.
title: Personal data breach case studies

_items.title: Deliberate data breach by an employee
_items.body:
An Employee of an insurance company passed on confidential customer information to a claims management company.

This is a breach of the GDPR as it results from deliberate action from a employee to offer access to an unauthorised third party.

This is a criminal offence and the individuals concerned could end up in court with a fine and a criminal record as well as losing their job.
_items.strapline: Deliberate data breach by an internal data processor

_items.title: Accidental data breach by an employee
_items.body: A member of staff of a government department emailed a spreadsheet containing personal data of 1,182 individuals to the wrong email address. This is a breach of GDPR because, whilst being accidental, the breach risked the welfare of the individuals involved in the breach, as well as their families.
_items.strapline: Accidental transfer of personal data outside the European Union

_items.title: Data theft by external hacker group
_items.body: A vigilante hacker group stole the user data of a commercial website through a phishing email. The group later leaked these user details. This is a breach of the GDPR because, whilst not a deliberate action by a data controller or processor, security flaws led to access by an unauthorized third party that resulted in a high risk to the rights of the individuals concerned.
_items.strapline: Data theft by external hacker group
